subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: I rather agree with Ted, even though i am in favour of some standardisation, but only on common words.  I have no difficulty in understanding US written
messageBody:
I rather agree with Ted, even though i am in favour of some standardisation, but only on common words.  I have no difficulty in understanding US written scripts if I read it with and "American" accent.  Likewise with any other accent - which one can usually deduce from the way certain words are written in QS.

So vive la difference, but lets keep, and maybe slightly expand upon, the standardised common words.

best

Moira

On 13/11/2007, Ted Larson Freeman <freeman@...> wrote:

I think the upshot of the lexical set discussion is that if used
intelligently, it can *greatly reduce* the differences between QS
written by people who speak with different accents. It will not
*eliminate* the differences. Look again at John Cowan's message (Nov.
6):
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/1353

Under "Group III" he says,

"Either BATH is like TRAP or BATH is like PALM; in the former case you
write BATH words with At, the same vowel as TRAP words; in the latter
case, with Ah, the same vowel as PALM words."

So an English and American QS scribe will write BATH words
differently. And that's OK. We already have different spellings, but
if I pick up a London newspaper I can read it as easily as I read the
New York Times.

In my view, here's the program: you go through the lexical sets, using
Anthony's charts or some web interface with check boxes or whatever
and you end up with a guide to using QS for your particular accent.
Then you stick to your own accent. Don't try to guess someone else's
accent. The user-testing that was done 40 years ago showed that this
system will allow effective communication across the major accents in
the English-speaking world.

QS has the expressive power to capture different accents, and that is
a strength, not a weakness. Let's use it.

Ted



On Nov 13, 2007 2:52 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
> > > So I want to use QS that is reasonable and readable for everyone.
> > >
> >
> > Just wondering: which accent are you trying to recreate?
> >
>
> My understanding is that lexical sets pretty much neutralize accents,
> no? I write "sit" with "If" as my vowel and hear it my own way; an
> Australian uses the same letter, though he hears a different sound. But
> we both can understand each other.
>
> If we are going to need different dictionaries for different accents,
> aren't we using something that is inferior to TO? The advantage with TO
> is that an Australian can pick up a novel written by an American and
> read it as quickly as if it were written by an Australian (with perhaps
> a few phrases he might not be aware of). If QS cannot reach across
> dialects in the same way, then it is inferior to TO, at least in this
> respect.
>
> At least the news might be bringing some of these issues to the surface
> so we can discuss them.
>
> Paul
>
>



--
Moira O'Brien
